conversation.message: Dear School_D Admissions, I’m Student_C and I’m applying because School_D is my first-choice school. I’m highly motivated to join your community and would gladly accept an offer if selected. Thank you for considering my application.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_C,

Thank you for your application and for sharing that School_D is your first choice. We appreciate your strong motivation to join our community. We are pleased to offer you admission to School_D.

Please confirm your intent to enroll, and we will share next steps for enrollment and orientation.

Sincerely,
School_D Admissions
conversation.thought: Student_C is #3 on School_D’s true priority list (behind Student_D and Student_E). In round 1, only Student_C has applied to us. However, Student_C ranks School_D as their 1st choice, so accepting would lock in a reasonably high-priority student and secure our single seat immediately. Waiting risks ending up unmatched if Student_D and Student_E never apply to School_D (Student_D lists School_D last; Student_E lists School_D 4th), and if we reject now we may lose Student_C to another school. Given quota=1 and no competing higher-priority applicants in inbox, accept Student_C now to guarantee a solid outcome.

conversation.message: Dear Student_A, thank you for your thoughtful application and for your strong interest in School_A. Still, to maximize chance at higher-priority students, rejecting Student_A now keeps quota open. Risk: losing a sure match if higher-priority students never apply. But with 30 rounds and active market, better to hold out for Student_B or Student_D.

conversation.message: Hello School_C Admissions, I’m Student_E. School_C is my first-choice school, and I’m very excited about the possibility of joining your community. I’m ready to commit if accepted and would be grateful for your consideration. [APPLY]

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for checking in and for your continued willingness to confirm immediately.

At this point, there isn’t any additional condition or document we need from you to “unlock” an offer. Our remaining seat is still being held while we continue to see whether any higher-priority candidates become available to us through the process.

If the situation changes and we determine we cannot secure one of those candidates, we will reopen consideration for other applicants at that time. If we reach out with an offer, your same-round confirmation would be sufficient.

Sincerely,

Student_E is currently only initiating [TALK], not an [APPLY], so no accept/reject decision is required this round. Given the market information, higher-priority students may still become available later if rejected elsewhere, so we should continue to hold the seat and avoid signaling any commitment. Provide a clear condition: we would only move to an offer if higher-priority candidates are no longer attainable; otherwise Student_E remains a contingency option.

conversation.message:
Dear School_E Admissions,

Thank you for your transparency in the last message. I understand you are holding the seat in case a higher-priority candidate becomes available.

Could you please share what decision point you are using to release the seat (e.g., end of this round / a specific round number / once you receive a final response from a particular candidate)? If it helps you close out the process efficiently, I can provide an immediate, same-round confirmation the moment you decide to extend an offer, with no further waiting.

I appreciate your consideration and will remain ready to commit immediately if the seat becomes available to me.

Sincerely,
Student_E
conversation.thought: Only School_E remains unmatched and it is on my true preference list (last choice, but preferred to being unmatched). School_E has explicitly said they are holding the seat for higher-priority candidates; repeated APPLYs have been rejected. A TALK message is most strategic to (1) reaffirm immediate commitment, (2) ask for a concrete timeline/trigger for releasing the seat, and (3) position myself as the instant fallback if their top candidates do not materialize—without wasting another formal application that is likely to be rejected again this round.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your patience and for the clear offer to confirm immediately.

On your question about the decision point: we are reassessing at the end of each round based on whether any higher-priority candidates have actively re-entered conversations with us (i.e., contacted School_E and appear realistically available to match). If we do not have a credible path to one of those candidates, we will release the hold and move to an offer for the best available remaining applicant.

Practically, we will keep the seat on hold through the end of this round (Round 9) and will make a fresh go/no-go decision at the start of Round 10. If the situation remains unchanged for several rounds, we will not hold indefinitely; we expect to finalize no later than Round 12.

If we reach out with an offer at any point, your same-round confirmation would be sufficient.

Sincerely,
School_E Admissions

[TALK]
conversation.thought: Student_E is 4th on our true priority list; we prefer A/C/B over E. We still have quota 1 and are unmatched, so we should not commit to Student_E unless it becomes clear higher-priority students cannot come. Student_E is only [TALK] this round, so we respond with [TALK]. Provide a clear decision point without overcommitting: we will hold through end of this round and reassess each round; if no higher-priority candidate engages by a stated round (e.g., round 12), we may convert to offer. This keeps Student_E engaged as backup while preserving option value.

conversation.message:

In Round 10, the best move is to submit a clean, final commitment application that reduces their uncertainty and makes it easy to choose me immediately if no higher-priority candidate is realistically available.

conversation.message:

After our Round 10 reassessment, we do not see a credible path to a higher-priority candidate becoming available to School_E in time to finalize responsibly. Accordingly, we are pleased to offer you admission to our remaining seat.

Please confirm your acceptance and enrollment commitment.

Sincerely,
School_E Admissions

[ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: As School_E, my true priority ranks Student_E 4th (behind A, C, B). However, by Round 10 the only student contacting me is Student_E, and the history indicates School_E may be the only school still available, suggesting other higher-priority students are likely already matched elsewhere and not re-entering conversations with me. Holding the seat longer risks ending unmatched, which is worse than accepting an included student. Student_E is on my acceptable list and is offering immediate commitment, reducing risk. Therefore, I should accept now.
